(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7585, 'date': '2014-06-11 10:38:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

So the best action will be to divide this spec into 2 specs.

As lifeless was pointing out "Is it alerting we want, or availability data, or both? I suspect many orgs will have alerting mechanisms in place, and perhaps we should be focused on collating the data to feed into e.g. alerting apps of various sorts."

1. I would like see this spec describing in detail how we will deploy check_mk infrastructure, that will be able to feed statistics into various endpoints (Ceilometer, Icinga, Nagios, etc.) 

There is obvious need to use the stats in multiple places, like proprietary alerting systems, TripleO-UI or monitoring solutions like Icinga.

The Triple-UI will be focused on special stuff related to management of the cloud. And will also allow to observe the hardware correlation with what is happening in openstack. So e.g. very high CPU/Memory usage or Temperature when there is nova-boot on the machine, etc. We can put any Openstack events into Ceilometer.

On the other hand Nagios/Icinga etc. solutions will focus on monitoring of Hardware without knowledge what is going on in higher levels. But that is very needed as well. Also this should monitor everything possible metric. And solving things like complex alerting, escalation, etc..

Plus alternatives to check_mk, right now we have SNMPd running on every machine, which can be polled with bulk request, which makes it also one query per node. We should avoid having multiple agents on the machines being polled from multiple sources. That is why we need an agent that will be usable for everybody.

Seems like popular deployment of Icinga is with mod_gearman, that doesn't play well with check_mk, that shoudl be mentioned.

2. The second spec should be about monitoring backend, frontend and reporting. (maybe separate specs for that too) Again describing detailed architecture(plans for distributed architecture and HA). From what data sources it can get the stats. Etc. How loosely coupled is Icinga frontend with the backend, can we switch it? Can the backed be just API based?'}, {'account_id': 7537, 'date': '2014-06-11 14:54:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

This spec addresses one thing and one thing only - how to get alert-based monitoring for system-level issues. I have tried my best to make it as modular and flexible as possible.

It is something that we can implement *today* (I have patchsets already that are fully tested and working across multiple devtest runs) and it gives us something that we do not currently have.

SNMPd != Alert-based monitoring.  If it did, then we would never have moved away from testing whether "snmpwalk <horrid_string>" matches a known good output.

It is my belief that we need to get an alert-based monitoring framework in place *first* and then have additional specs for how we are going to include that data into other projects once we know what those projects are going to look like.  I'm not convinced it makes sense for us to be writing specs on how systems will interact with the monitoring solution before the monitoring solution has even been implemented!

Check_MK allows us to switch between Icinga, Nagios and the check_mk native web interface as the user prefers (although at present my code only allows for Icinga) and the flexible nature of check_mk means that there should be few issues integrating with other monitoring solutions in future.

The primary reasons for choosing check_mk as the monitoring agent were as follows:

1)	The agent responds via a simple telnet connection to port 6556 and returns monitoring results (along with performance data where available) in a well-documented, open, plain text format providing an easy way to integrate with other systems that do not/will not use check_mk server.
2)	Check_MK is released under the GPL v2 - a license acceptable to most large organisations
3)	A large amount of checks (including Network Interfaces, Disk space/IO, Kernel Page Faults/Context Switches, Memory and CPU information) are automatically available out of the box
4)	Adding new checks is as simple as placing an executable in a directory on the host you wish to monitor.  The new check will be picked up without a need to refresh/restart the service on the next request for information

I cannot stress enough that whilst I have chosen to use Icinga for the web interface, Icinga is doing very little work and could easily be replaced by something else.

Metrics != Alerts.  My personal preference for collecting and monitoring metrics would be statsd/collectd+graphite, however my understanding is that it is *metric collection* that Ceilometer is designed to deal with and therefore I have deliberately left graphing/trending/etc. out of this spec.

Icinga+mod_gearman is an alternative approach to solving the same scalability issue that check_mk solves, hence the fact that they are incompatible.  As using mod_gearman is a different (and arguably more complex) approach to this problem then I am happy to put it into the spec as an Alternative, however I do not feel it deserves much more of a mention than that given that most large scale icinga deployments I am aware of use check_mk, not mod_gearman.'}, {'account_id': 9712, 'date': '2014-06-17 10:35:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-17 10:36:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: -Verified

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-17 11:12:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified+1

Build succeeded.

- gate-tripleo-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/50/91750/5/check/gate-tripleo-specs-python27/883d314 : SUCCESS in 54s
- gate-tripleo-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/50/91750/5/check/gate-tripleo-specs-docs/8c50514/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 07s'}, {'account_id': 7537, 'date': '2014-06-17 11:44:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7585, 'date': '2014-06-20 07:05:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Ok so you are pointing that SNMPd != Alert-based monitoring and Metrics != Alerts.

But all the Alerts are based on the metrics, right? Does it mean this solution doesn't store the metrics, only alerts that were inferred from them?

The reason I want to know upfront if check_mk metrics will be usable and can replace SNMPd, is that we don't run multiple agents on the host. This needs to have a plan, not just start to put things to host and then figuring out how to merge them. 

Like right now we have SNMPd agent, that can be used as source for Nagios alerts. And as a source of metrics for Ceilometer.

So I would like to see somewhere in the list of steps of this spec, how to configure this via heat, so I can add e.g. Ceilometer endpoint for receiving the stats. How to handle authentication. How to make live checks from Ceilometer. (and not just Ceilometer, in general manner) Before we put it in as one true solution, this should all be designed."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-07 06:43:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: -Verified

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 7537, 'date': '2014-07-07 06:43:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Hi Ladislav :)

Whilst I understand your desire to run as few agents as possible on a host (and as a basic premise I agree that this is a Good Thing), I feel that there are things that check_mk provide to us that SNMP will not.

With check_mk, I can write a script (using capybara or similar) that goes to Horizon, logs in, spawns an instance via the web interface, checks that the web interface believes that instance launched, logs into the API and retrieves the IP Address of the instance just launched by the script via the web interface and then connects to the in stance via SSH.  The script then reports in a very simple fashion:

0 horizon_and_api_working - Instance Launch Successful
1 horizon_and_api_working - Instance not yet ready
2 horizon_and_api_working - Instance <uuid> Failed to Launch
3 horizon_and_api_working - An unknown error occurred

This is consumed by check_mk and fed to icinga/nagios/whatever without the need to find and allocate an OID or have knowledge of how the monitoring system works (my understanding is that I would need to understand SNMP and how it all hangs together in order to write a check that reports a metric).

Note that in the above example I do not report any data about how long something has taken, how many resources are being used or anything else, it is just a simple OK (0), WARN (1), ERROR (2) or UNKNOWN (3) alert and this is what check_mk does well.

Check_MK could (if you really wanted to!) even run tempest against your production system and alert on the results of a full tempest run once every hour however at present I am struggling to see how to achieve the same thing with SNMP.

If you are in agreement with this as an approach, then I am happy to update the blueprint to reflect the above conversation in the "Alternatives" section with a view to exploring how to extend check_mk in future to put messages onto the queue in a format that Ceilometer can understand at a future date.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-07 06:44:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified+1

Build succeeded.

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 215, 'date': '2014-07-22 13:26:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-22 13:31:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified+1

Build succeeded.

- gate-tripleo-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/50/91750/5/check/gate-tripleo-specs-docs/359becd/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 58s'}, {'account_id': 7585, 'date': '2014-08-06 12:07:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

'If you are in agreement with this as an approach, then I am happy to update the blueprint to reflect the above conversation in the "Alternatives" section with a view to exploring how to extend check_mk in future to put messages onto the queue in a format that Ceilometer can understand at a future date.'

Yes I would like to see plan for this. So we can possibly have only one agent in the future. (if check_mk can just wrap SNMP)

In addition I think you should mention that running another Agent on every node can have security impact and probably performance impact.


Other than that I think the spec has now a clear goal and it is acceptable. :-)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-08-06 12:07:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: -Verified

commit_message:
Spec to accompany systems-monitoring blueprint

subject: Re-assert System State

If I'm a sysadmin, can I disable this automatic reversion for longer than the standard period? (I'm wondering about "leasing" the right to a change - for your first use case you might be looking at days between a quick workaround and a new release to production.)

I think it'd be good to teach os-svc-daemon about configuration files: that is, when a service is registered, we also tell the system which configuration files we care about for that service.

(That'd let us shift much of this capability into os-svc-restart, I think; although the o-a-c stage would still need to collaborate with it.)'}, {'account_id': 7537, 'date': '2014-07-03 13:58:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Patch Set 1:
>  If I'm a sysadmin, can I disable this automatic reversion for longer than the standard period? (I'm wondering about "leasing" the right to a change - for your first use case you might be looking at days between a quick workaround and a new release to production.)

Yes, you stop os-collect-config and we make sure that there is an alert in the monitoring system that shows it as stopped, that way you remember to restart it.  

If we give people the ability to "lease" the right to a change, then they'll just set it to 42e100 days and o-c-c will never run again.

> I think it'd be good to teach os-svc-daemon about configuration files: that is, when a service is registered, we also tell the system which configuration files we care about for that service. (That'd let us shift much of this capability into os-svc-restart, I think; although the o-a-c stage would still need to collaborate with it.)

I agree, this is a good idea and I'd like to move towards it.'}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2014-07-04 14:04:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-09 11:06:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Verified

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 6969, 'date': '2014-07-16 18:23:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I agree in principal with all these.

But there is a bigger issue underneath that I would like addressed here (or in a spec that this depends on, or a bug) is that we can configuring services in os-*, but then we hand over control to the underlying OS system start via os-svc-enable

Different OS's handle this differently and this has caused (causing) me a lot of issues. For example mysql starting before nova / neutron. My recent issue is that mysql in a cluster won't start via upstart but if I run os-refresh-config it does. Also the system start scripts generally run before os-collect-config so we can have a cases where if a machine is down for any reason, your cloud stack changes and then the machine comes back online we currently will end up starting services with an old configuration. Then o-r-c will run reconfigure, and restart the services. While I haven't hit this problem we will at the current rate and this could be very messy.

Also this should simplify things and help developers with cross distro issues. I haven't put any time into fedora but I believe by implementing this we will narrow the difference between distros and can be confident that stuff that starts in ubuntu will start in fedora and vice versa. 

Having o-r-c to be in control of starting services will also help with upgrades and db migrations. After an update, we don't want to start certain services till the db migrations have successfully run.

I believe that in order for this spec to be implemented in full this issue about system services needs to be addressed first. As it will dictate how a lot of this will work.

I have started work on bug #1334804 which forces o-c-c to run o-r-c on boot even if no meta data changes. From the bug this is because we need to reassert ephemeral state but I also want to start services."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-16 18:27:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded.

- gate-tripleo-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/24/104524/1/check/gate-tripleo-specs-python27/e815724 : SUCCESS in 1m 49s
- gate-tripleo-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/24/104524/1/check/gate-tripleo-specs-docs/f1edc1f/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 30s'}, {'account_id': 7537, 'date': '2014-07-17 06:17:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Hi Michael,

I'll be honest, I think this spec is big enough already without having to add control of services at system boot etc. to it.

If you can submit a new spec, I'm happy to add it as a reference here and we can talk in #tripleo about how we're going to deal with it re: dependency etc.

Cheers,

Matt"}, {'account_id': 7471, 'date': '2014-07-21 17:51:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

[{'created': '2014-07-03 11:25:39.000000000', 'message': 'Re-assert System State

This spec sets out a methodology to ensure that any changes made
to system state outside of HEAT are overwritten with the correct
configuration from HEAT.

Change-Id: I983bb3e4b064699f768aaa37375044777322d45d
'}]
commit_message:
Re-assert System State

This spec sets out a methodology to ensure that any changes made
to system state outside of HEAT are overwritten with the correct
configuration from HEAT.

Change-Id: I983bb3e4b064699f768aaa37375044777322d45d

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-10-28 13:59:24.000000000', 'message': "XenServer: Fix initramfs scripts

During bashate -ing some files with .sh extension has been modified,
which are interpreted with /bin/sh, which takes a different syntax.
Fixing the issue:
    - rename the files, so they are not picked up
    - use syntax that's understood by sh

Change-Id: I617b24813df86687ca33745d0c940b0c659f2e14
"}]
commit_message:
XenServer: Fix initramfs scripts

During bashate -ing some files with .sh extension has been modified,
which are interpreted with /bin/sh, which takes a different syntax.
Fixing the issue:
    - rename the files, so they are not picked up
    - use syntax that's understood by sh

Change-Id: I617b24813df86687ca33745d0c940b0c659f2e14

commit_message:
vmware-split-backend-logic

Specification of the plan for moving backend logic from the VMware
plugin into a separate module.

Change-Id: If39f119b37c55ecfef0d016226b7245fdcfe190d

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-10-28 15:47:51.000000000', 'message': 'Make RequestContext use auth_token (not auth_tok)

The RequestContext class from oslo-incubator uses 'auth_token'.
Glance's RequestContext uses 'auth_tok' -- which is inconsistent.

glance_store currently uses the oslo 'auth_token'.

We should not assume a 1-1 mapping from the glance_store to glance,
nor should we have glance_store support both 'auth_token' and
'auth_tok'. Therefore Glance should be updated to use 'auth_token'.

This change was generated automatically with:

$ for file in `find glance -name '*\.py' -exec grep -wl auth_tok "{}" \;` ; \
  do sed --in-place 's/\<auth_tok\>/auth_token/g' $file ; done

In addition, the set_auth_token function was removed. This had been used
by Nova to work around the auth_tok <-> auth_token inconsistency, but
was removed in mid-2012 as part of the move to python-glanceclient so
is no longer needed.

In conjuction with other changes this fixes image upload when
using the multi-tenant Swift store.

Change-Id: Ic8a5f44088990fd8f6290a5622b823f59ef365fc
Partial-bug: #1385213
'}]
commit_message:
Make RequestContext use auth_token (not auth_tok)

The RequestContext class from oslo-incubator uses 'auth_token'.
Glance's RequestContext uses 'auth_tok' -- which is inconsistent.

glance_store currently uses the oslo 'auth_token'.

We should not assume a 1-1 mapping from the glance_store to glance,
nor should we have glance_store support both 'auth_token' and
'auth_tok'. Therefore Glance should be updated to use 'auth_token'.

This change was generated automatically with:

$ for file in `find glance -name '*\.py' -exec grep -wl auth_tok "{}" \;` ; \
  do sed --in-place 's/\<auth_tok\>/auth_token/g' $file ; done

In addition, the set_auth_token function was removed. This had been used
by Nova to work around the auth_tok <-> auth_token inconsistency, but
was removed in mid-2012 as part of the move to python-glanceclient so
is no longer needed.

In conjuction with other changes this fixes image upload when
using the multi-tenant Swift store.

Change-Id: Ic8a5f44088990fd8f6290a5622b823f59ef365fc
Partial-bug: #1385213

commit_message:
Remove unused py33 tox env

It's apparent that Nova is quite a ways from Py3K support, and
developers are not expected to run the py33 tox env. Rather than add
more envs for later Python interpreter versions which will be
equally broken, just remove it for now.

Change-Id: I885e6e8899f771cc52a2bf6282fd7bc1ed3083aa
(cherry picked from commit fd297c108aba920bf3de43c29843425884253857)

commit_message:
Add '--xxx' only argument type for client cli

Beside the command type "<client> --key=<value> <command>", there is
other type of command type "<client> --key <command>" for example
"keystone --insecure tenant-list". Add this command argument type
into consideration.

Change-Id: I6bb97279ef380eb71ac581f8cd99623ab7d1519e

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-09-22 22:48:16.000000000', 'message': "Remove unused py33 tox env

Based on review comments in https://review.openstack.org/118771 it's
apparent that Cinder is quite a ways from Py3K support, and
developers are not expected to run the py33 tox env. Rather than add
more envs for later Python interpreter versions which will be
equally broken, just remove it for now.

Change-Id: I2bcc345bb62c0e08677fbf70b722b6a841650e53
(cherry picked from commit b1c572df49270b99ab0d221b9f96492d121595cd)
"}]
commit_message:
Remove unused py33 tox env

Based on review comments in https://review.openstack.org/118771 it's
apparent that Cinder is quite a ways from Py3K support, and
developers are not expected to run the py33 tox env. Rather than add
more envs for later Python interpreter versions which will be
equally broken, just remove it for now.

Change-Id: I2bcc345bb62c0e08677fbf70b722b6a841650e53
(cherry picked from commit b1c572df49270b99ab0d221b9f96492d121595cd)

commit_message:
Fix wrong example of capabilities

Capabilities for storage is "storage:production_ready", but the
sample of Capabilities for storage is only "production_ready",
which cause wrong description in document, and misleading developers.

Change-Id: I98da1908ca99d9a20e0cbf367b73275da09f9f82

[{'created': '2014-11-05 10:08:22.000000000', 'message': 'Fix glance_image for local images

When trying to upload an image from the local file system, the
resource provider was failing. Fixing it to use the --file option
for the glance client instead of going through stdin.

Change-Id: Ic6bade025d28e2eb33f86c2d4421b65d06e8274c
'}]
commit_message:
Fix glance_image for local images

When trying to upload an image from the local file system, the
resource provider was failing. Fixing it to use the --file option
for the glance client instead of going through stdin.

Change-Id: Ic6bade025d28e2eb33f86c2d4421b65d06e8274c

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-11-04 11:17:23.000000000', 'message': "Reuse addresses from dhcp pool when possible

We can get rid from static pool, by reusing dhcp
address, assigned to node initially.

General procedure for assignment of ip addresses
is not changed, but i've added one more condition
to check if ip address is in range of admin_net.ip_range
if it is - it will be reused when creating ip address
if not - address will be used from pool, it will guarantee
that patch works on upgraded environments

Also made refactoring of old code

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: 1271571
Implments: blueprint get-gid-of-splitted-fueladmin-network

Change-Id: I1fcc4532faa6b255674b589ebd44534082e29c96

commit_message:
Reuse addresses from dhcp pool when possible

We can get rid from static pool, by reusing dhcp
address, assigned to node initially.

General procedure for assignment of ip addresses
is not changed, but i've added one more condition
to check if ip address is in range of admin_net.ip_range
if it is - it will be reused when creating ip address
if not - address will be used from pool, it will guarantee
that patch works on upgraded environments

Also made refactoring of old code

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: 1271571
Implments: blueprint get-gid-of-splitted-fueladmin-network

commit_message:
Improve documentation of run_tests.sh script

Fix typos and change a few sentences of run_tests.sh script.
Also insert punctuation marks in several sentences of help message
to keep a pattern.

Change-Id: I554905f619ff3c5300b2e2603f247596816ac945

commit_message:
Correct the mongodb_replica_set option's description

Current description for mongodb_replica_set is wrong, this patch
fixes it.

Change-Id: I0121beb7a71a282eb73b48d7a7fd4dccb0d36a31
DocImpact

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

commit_message:
Fix misaligned actions on table toolbar

Fixed the misaligned action buttons on the table toolbar when the
browser is resized to be narrow.   Before this patch the filter fields and
buttons are dispalyed out of place when resizing the browser narrow.

Change-Id: I91cd6555a6a6e79b43134cbaa4ade0e2819ea6d2
Closes-Bug: #1357591

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 105, 'name': 'Kyle Mestery', 'email': 'mestery@mestery.com', 'username': 'mestery'}, {'_account_id': 261, 'name': 'Salvatore Orlando', 'email': 'salv.orlando@gmail.com', 'username': 'salvatore-orlando'}, {'_account_id': 1112, 'name': 'Everett Toews', 'email': 'everett.toews@rackspace.com', 'username': 'everett-toews'}, {'_account_id': 2592, 'name': 'Mark McClain', 'email': 'mark@mcclain.xyz', 'username': 'markmcclain'}, {'_account_id': 5292, 'name': 'Christopher Yeoh', 'email': 'cbkyeoh@gmail.com', 'username': 'cyeoh-0'}, {'_account_id': 6167, 'name': "Ken'ichi Ohmichi", 'email': 'ken1ohmichi@gmail.com', 'username': 'oomichi'}, {'_account_id': 6854, 'name': 'YAMAMOTO Takashi', 'email': 'yamamoto@midokura.com', 'username': 'yamamoto'}]

[{'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2014-10-29 02:19:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-10-29 02:20:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-neutron-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/23/131623/1/check/gate-neutron-specs-docs/a9f1e7c/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 37s
- gate-neutron-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/23/131623/1/check/gate-neutron-specs-python27/404d1b4 : SUCCESS in 1m 29s'}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2014-10-29 12:47:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

This looks ok to me, and I'm onboard with this direction."}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2014-10-29 15:02:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

See this thread here[1], it appears we need greater oversight into these flags before we start merging things requiring arbitrary commit flags.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-October/049438.html'}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2014-10-29 15:19:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

REST interfaces are important and we cannot change them easily after publishing them.
So we need to pay attention for REST API changes and some flag like this would be helpful for getting attentions.'}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2014-10-29 22:40:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@kyle - we have merged this into Nova  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/129757/ and I've been trying to spread it around to the other projects so we have a common way to find REST API related spec changes.

Also this only applies to specs, not code commits so its wider impact is fairly limited (developers won't have to wade through them when looking at log messages for code). 

For code changes we can often use the files changed as search key for what has changed but we're not able to do that with specs."}, {'account_id': 6854, 'date': '2014-10-30 03:45:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

have you considered automation?
eg. have a bot to find out non-empty "REST API Impact" section and
post a comment in a way gerrit query can find it.'}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2014-10-30 11:33:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yea, thought about it, but this seemed much simpler. Pulling down every single spec in openstack (each time its updated) seems like quite a bit of work. We've merged the change in Nova specs repository. And the API WG was hoping that other projects would also adopt the convention to make it fairly easy for us to find API related specs."}, {'account_id': 1112, 'date': '2014-10-31 16:45:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2014-11-08 22:27:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

After discussion at the summit API-WG session in the cross project track, the consensus seems to be that this is a good idea.  I'd like to see us use it."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2014-11-10 12:05:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-11-10 12:05:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Verified

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-11-10 12:10:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+2

Build succeeded (gate pipeline).

- gate-neutron-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/23/131623/1/gate/gate-neutron-specs-docs/4db26a8/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 31s
- gate-neutron-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/23/131623/1/gate/gate-neutron-specs-python27/074d30f : SUCCESS in 2m 34s'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-11-10 12:10:29.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

[{'created': '2014-10-29 02:19:02.000000000', 'message': 'Add requirement for APIImpact flag

Adds a requirement for an APIImpact flag in
the commit message for a proposed spec if it proposes
changes to the Neutron REST API. This will make it
much easier for people such as the API WG who want to
review API changes across OpenStack to find and
review proposed API changes.

Change-Id: I21f1b9c645bd40b8c1f2e5e627c4dd5a667431dc
'}]
commit_message:
Add requirement for APIImpact flag

Adds a requirement for an APIImpact flag in
the commit message for a proposed spec if it proposes
changes to the Neutron REST API. This will make it
much easier for people such as the API WG who want to
review API changes across OpenStack to find and
review proposed API changes.

Change-Id: I21f1b9c645bd40b8c1f2e5e627c4dd5a667431dc

commit_message:
Add fix with floating_ip_pool for ui tests

Added fix for applying floating_ip_pool
on create node group template.
Added fix for hide/show full configuraton
on create node group template.

Change-Id: I1d966493a28ce43a09ec4970f965eb0542474d1c
closes-bug: #1383266
closes-bug: #1383267

[{'created': '2014-11-07 16:11:17.000000000', 'message': "fuel_upgrade: add hack to make repo symlink

We need to add next symlink

    repo/ubuntu/x86_64 -> repo/ubuntu/fuelweb/x86_64

in order to get working upgrade to 6.0, because in 6.0 we know nothing
about 'fuelweb' folder in repo struct, but we have it in old repos from
previous installation.

Change-Id: I7985a1f64b54bfff84df7098252448ea6ec6b613
Closes-Bug: #1390521
"}, {'created': '2014-11-07 16:49:07.000000000', 'message': "fuel_upgrade: add hack to make repo symlink

We need to add next symlink

    repo/ubuntu/x86_64 -> repo/ubuntu/fuelweb/x86_64

in order to get working upgrade to 6.0, because in 6.0 we know nothing
about 'fuelweb' folder in repo struct, but we have it in old repos from
previous installation.

Change-Id: I7985a1f64b54bfff84df7098252448ea6ec6b613
Closes-Bug: #1390521
"}]
commit_message:
fuel_upgrade: add hack to make repo symlink

We need to add next symlink

    repo/ubuntu/x86_64 -> repo/ubuntu/fuelweb/x86_64

in order to get working upgrade to 6.0, because in 6.0 we know nothing
about 'fuelweb' folder in repo struct, but we have it in old repos from
previous installation.

Change-Id: I7985a1f64b54bfff84df7098252448ea6ec6b613
Closes-Bug: #1390521

[{'created': '2014-11-07 14:04:01.000000000', 'message': "Save fuel_version field for plugins model

It's important to keep all of the information
which plugin provides about dependencies.
In the future versions there might be cases
when we have to write some workaround not to
brake old plugins.

Change-Id: Id0f45def2972a60040e3a1d2a016a1ed46a05ed3
Implements: blueprint cinder-neutron-plugins-in-fuel
"}]
commit_message:
Save fuel_version field for plugins model

It's important to keep all of the information
which plugin provides about dependencies.
In the future versions there might be cases
when we have to write some workaround not to
brake old plugins.

Change-Id: Id0f45def2972a60040e3a1d2a016a1ed46a05ed3
Implements: blueprint cinder-neutron-plugins-in-fuel

Print error message if one of containers failed

Show an error message if one or more containers failed to pass
"dockerctl check" tests.

Ihar,

In master, commit e6ea26ea1272f9407879b822b3913b4308e3f2f8 for bug1365881 changed this volumeref to the value we want.  This one-line change arguably should not have been part of that commit, which is really about something else,
but in master that commit came later than the commit we are cherrypicking here and it would be a mistake to override the later volumeref value with the earlier one.

Note that the later master commit e6ea26ea1272f9407879b822b3913b4308e3f2f8 has already been cherry-picked into icehouse via 
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/128012/.  We are not surreptitiously bringing part of it into icehouse, but are rather dealing with a minor merge conflict in this cherrypick.

So this confusion comes from the fact that the order of commits in master and of the corresponding backports in icehouse is reversed (that's just an accident of how fast the reviews for the backports for each of these went) and the (in my view) dubious practice of packing a one line correction to a unit-test for "already-mapped" tests into a commit that otherwise dealt solely with controller preferred path.'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2014-10-30 17:11:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Ihar, I think I've sorted out the source of the confusion here.  We do want the value that is in this change set and I'm not "sneaking" it in :-) but I totally see why what we're doing wasn't clear.'}, {'account_id': 9656, 'date': '2014-10-31 16:58:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

commit_message:
NetApp fix attach fail for already mapped volume

This patch fixes the error raised during mapping of a volume
to the host during attach operation if the volume is already
mapped to the host.

Change-Id: I4f711e7ac18eea0dfddab65fd85a3601fe967a88
Closes-bug: #1310659
(cherry picked from commit dcec1b84f4d3462fc408f4152f4c89b8df79d629)

commit_message:
Fix KeyError in md_utils in fuel-agent

fuel-agent failed after reset cluster and re-deploy while creating
new md device if inactive devices were found

Change-Id: I38f086fae7e7c5cd2a62669509538e8ddbb092b2
Closes-Bug: #1390492

commit_message:
Extract version definition to a separate file

Before, version was stores in the init file.
It's better not to store such kind of public data
as version to init file.
Moreover, whole murano package needed to be imported to identify project version
Now, separate file is used for that

Also, doc builder config was updated to support this change

Change-Id: Iede1dfbe9ae4d8c6fb5ecdeb8f8f25124e4bc34f

Looks good, is it possible to create a test case exposing this rare error case?'}, {'account_id': 7711, 'date': '2014-10-15 08:11:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

The problem description in commit message looks like a bug, please create bugreport. Also agree with Dmitry.'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2014-10-15 09:11:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Hi Chris,

This patch is conflicting with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/128463/ which one you want to maintain?

(+ a test would be good as @Dmitry pointed out)

Thanks'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2014-10-16 22:08:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I fixed the other review... I didn't mean for it to include this fix.

For something this trivial, I'm not feeling like a bug or a test is necessary. Feel free to take this patch over, if you feel otherwise..."}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2014-10-17 09:51:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

In general, test is required for _every_ bug fix to

1. prove that you really fixed it (otherwise how do we check?)

2. to avoid it regressing in the future'}, {'account_id': 7711, 'date': '2014-10-17 10:46:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

Chris, my personal opinion: bugreports are important. Anyone who uses Ironic and found a problem should have possibility to find it in the "knowing bug list" (with status, fixed in master branch or not).'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2014-10-22 17:05:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think this is a bug only when you screw up new code... (as I was when I was refactoring agent image writing)...and is not really a bug in the current code. However, doing this will prevent a future bug from being created.

How do you feel about it that case?'}, {'account_id': 7711, 'date': '2014-10-24 09:00:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Chris, OK, took off -1.'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2014-10-24 10:18:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Hi Chris,

Thanks for the update. The patch no longer conflicts with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/128463/ so I'm grand with the change."}, {'account_id': 7882, 'date': '2014-10-30 09:44:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2014-10-31 13:22:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

This makes sense to me, it's just defensive coding."}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2014-10-31 13:26:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I am personally against writing fixes for bugs that might exist some day. If it is a real thing that exists _already_ there should be a test so that it does not regress.'}, {'account_id': 3099, 'date': '2014-10-31 13:33:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

This fix looks fine to me, but I agree with Dmitry that we should have a test case here.'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2014-10-31 13:44:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2014-10-31 13:46:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

Thanks Chris, Jim'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2014-10-31 13:47:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3099, 'date': '2014-10-31 13:48:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

commit_message:
Fix traceback on rare agent error case

If self._deploy_is_done() fails for any reason when called on a agent
heartbeat, 'msg' was not set, creating a traceback when trying to log
it. Let's set a default.

Co-Authored-By: Jim Rollenhagen <jim@jimrollenhagen.com>

Change-Id: I7399821019bab4e3cf08324ee3314c40467e00a4

commit_message:
Refactor CLI tests

- tearDown logic was updated. Now we collect all test items and then
delete only them.

Closes-Bug: #1386804

Change-Id: I95193ad89d7db44c100b93cec7bf0c1d3db23209

@Sean, as per the bug report, in this patch I have addressed the issues associated with router-interface-add for subnets whose gateway_ip is either not-specified/specified as part of subnet cidr. 
https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1382076/comments/3

Now coming back to your question "are we able to use LLA address?" - I'm afraid, the answer is NO. We get a different error than the one reported in the bug. The error is from the following line - https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/db/db_base_plugin_v2.py#L449

Since it is a slightly different use-case, are you fine if we take it up as part of different bug/patch or do you think its better to address it in the current patch? Please let me know.'}, {'account_id': 6635, 'date': '2014-10-27 10:42:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-10-21 10:24:26.000000000', 'message': 'Cannot add router interface to IPv6 SLAAC network

Neutron should allow an IPv6 subnet configured with SLAAC
(or dhcpv6-stateless) to be attached to a router interface.
Currently this is broken, this patch fixes the issue.

Details of the fix (will remove this message and add testcases
after receiving some review comments).
Neutron allocates the gateway_ip (if not specified) to the first IP address
in the subnet CIDR and the gateway_ip is stored as part of subnet details.
So, by the time the request to attach the subnet gateway to the router is
received, the gateway_ip is already allocated/reserved in the subnet.

For this particular bug, there are two cases to consider...
1. When the gateway_ip is not specified as part of subnet creation.
2. Gateway_ip is specified and is part of subnet CIDR.

For the first case, IMO it would be ideal if Neutron does not reserve
any gateway_ip address in create_subnet and allocate (based on EUI-64
addressing - as MAC address is allocated only during port creation)
it only when the request to attach to the router interface is seen.
On the other hand, if the user creates the subnet with gateway_ip which
is part of subnet CIDR, we can modify Neutron to check the port owner
and if it happens to be the router, accept it.

Closes-Bug: #1382076
Change-Id: If0c48a7287a828eef4a0f0b0859d4f898d2937bd
'}, {'created': '2014-10-22 20:54:38.000000000', 'message': 'Cannot add router interface to IPv6 SLAAC network

commit_message:
Allow to add router interface to IPv6 SLAAC network

This patch will allow an IPv6 subnet configured with SLAAC
(or dhcpv6-stateless) to be attached to a router interface.

Closes-Bug: #1382076
Change-Id: If0c48a7287a828eef4a0f0b0859d4f898d2937bd

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be

commit_message:
Fix missing keyboard focus from Console's iframe

The iframe in Instance Console doesn't get focus on loading, so the user
cannot type into the console, this change is focusing for console iframe
on loading

Closes-Bug: #1389117
Change-Id: Idfb731c9a00506ad4d29174d92476d10316de05c

commit_message:
Fix image-builder scripts

* Fix encoding issues
* Convert all files to UTF-8
* Fix indendation and hanging whitespaces
* Add new vairable LIBVIRT_IMAGES_DIR to be able to use faster drive for KVM images
* Fix unattended template for sysrep on Windows Server 2008 R2

Change-Id: Ifb4df8c0eeddf1698a6e4c691f48e92406bac770

- noop http://logs.openstack.org/00/129700/2/check/noop/e95df72 : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2014-10-20 18:48:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-10-20 18:48:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- noop http://logs.openstack.org/00/129700/3/check/noop/0953e98 : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 7156, 'date': '2014-10-20 19:27:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

I was about to write about how I felt the manifest did "too much":
- user creation (user management)
- role assignation (assignment management)
- service / endpoints (catalog management)

But then I saw that it would be possible to disable management for each of them. I however feel the name is inadequate to express what this manifest actually accomplish, it's not just about pure identity. It's about a service's identity in Keystone? How about openstacklib::service_identity or something similar to make it clearer?

I however strongly feel the manifest introduces unnecessary granularity: protocol, host, port, suffix, etc.

I suggest we replace all those by the actual URL and stop the mess now:
- public_url
- internal_url
- admin_url

What about Keystone v3 which allows you to create service users in specific domains?

We also have to think about services with multiple versions like Nova for example: v2 and v3. How will it be addressed and used by a deployer/operator?

How about services introducing multiple API endpoints? (like the ec2 compatible API in Nova). How is it planned to support it?

What about multiple regions sharing the same keystone installation/catalog? In any of our modules, you cannot provision multiple regions due to the use of classes which can only be included once. What should we suggest deployers/operators to do if they wish to have multiple regions?

I guess this could be answered by the fact that you cannot have a controller handling requests for more than one region. I can however reply that I concentrated all endpoint management on a dedicated keystone controller. Therefore my Nova controller does not have /etc/keystone/keystone.conf available to handle keystone ressources/endpoints.

That's it for now. =)'}, {'account_id': 7156, 'date': '2014-10-20 19:31:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2014-10-21 08:20:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2014-10-21 14:00:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-10-21 14:00:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified+1

I wrote something really similar here:

https://github.com/aptira/puppet-stacktira/blob/master/manifests/openstack/service_auth.pp

and the multi-region things are done by these:

https://github.com/aptira/puppet-stacktira/blob/master/manifests/openstack/regions.pp

I think you can do a better job than I did making a neat wrapper. Perhaps if we made the module service classes into defined types that would make multi-region a lot easier.'}, {'account_id': 7155, 'date': '2014-10-22 19:53:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Two typo, otherwise it's ok for me. With regards to creating tenants and users, how should it be handled? The options seem to be:

* Do so directly against the endpoint (with aviator, maybe duplicating code).
* Use the tenant/user resources from puppet-keystone (creating a circular dependency, which may not be a problem in Puppet).
* Move the tenant/user resources into the library (breaking the keystone abstraction metaphor).'}, {'account_id': 6908, 'date': '2014-10-28 16:52:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

(3 comments)

Looks good to me.  I added a few comments where I suspect typos.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2014-10-28 17:55:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

@Chris:
> Do so directly against the endpoint (with aviator, maybe duplicating code).
For now, we won't use aviator, since it's not merged yet in puppet-keystone.

> Use the tenant/user resources from puppet-keystone (creating a circular dependency, which may not be a problem in Puppet).
will figure that out to ensure we don't have this problem, great point.

> Move the tenant/user resources into the library (breaking the keystone abstraction metaphor).
it's the goal of this BP."}, {'account_id': 7156, 'date': '2014-10-29 23:54:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

Looks fine to me. Would be nice to fix typo and half-written sentence.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2014-10-30 05:35:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-10-30 05:35:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Verified+1

commit_message:
Add support for list and map types

Add support to describe properties with
list and map types and provide validation.

Change-Id: I823b49126c9d416879a3248ea71cfe3e5efef087
Implements: blueprint tosca-list-and-map-wd2

commit_message:
Replace "nova" entries in iptables_manager with "neutron"

In iptables_manager docstrings there are still some references to
nova left from nova/network/linux_net.py.
Remove these references and update the docstrings.

Change-Id: I50813e3050f7f117512bde7c2563ce3410939e54
Closes-Bug: #1389601

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-11-07 14:17:45.000000000', 'message': 'Remove ephemeral size assertion in baremetal scenario

The test currently fails if the the baremetal flavor has no
ephemeral disk set.  This removes an unnecessary assertion and
unblocks tests against environments that do not deploy ephemeral
disks.

Change-Id: I7f13d4d7b40ea8879eaa30a19c117aef284586ff
'}]
commit_message:
Remove ephemeral size assertion in baremetal scenario

The test currently fails if the the baremetal flavor has no
ephemeral disk set.  This removes an unnecessary assertion and
unblocks tests against environments that do not deploy ephemeral
disks.

Change-Id: I7f13d4d7b40ea8879eaa30a19c117aef284586ff

[{'created': '2014-07-03 02:11:21.000000000', 'message': 'First try adding moving-averages to Gnocchi using InfluxDB

Created a separate file for rolling statistics functions,
first try at implementing a rolling mean in the
get_measures API using InfluxDB as the storage backend.

Change-Id: If40e58480f1512dd17b9c09cb75fd54c7193c257
'}, {'created': '2014-07-03 15:53:23.000000000', 'message': 'First try adding moving-averages to Gnocchi using InfluxDB

Created a separate file for rolling statistics functions,
first try at implementing a rolling mean in the
get_measures API using InfluxDB as the storage backend.

To get the moving-average in a query:

GET /v1/entity/UUID/measures?aggregation=moving-average

The window size is currently set to be the granularity specified
upon entity creation.

Change-Id: If40e58480f1512dd17b9c09cb75fd54c7193c257
'}, {'created': '2014-07-03 16:06:45.000000000', 'message': 'First try adding moving-averages to Gnocchi using InfluxDB

Change-Id: If40e58480f1512dd17b9c09cb75fd54c7193c257
'}, {'created': '2014-07-03 16:16:19.000000000', 'message': 'First try adding moving-averages to Gnocchi using InfluxDB

Created a separate file for rolling statistics functions,
first try at implementing a rolling mean in the
get_measures API using InfluxDB as the storage backend.

To get the moving-average in a query:

GET /v1/entity/UUID/measures?aggregation=moving-average

or

GET /v1/entity/UUID/measures?aggregation=moving-average&
	granularity=30

If granularity is not specified, the window size for the
moving average defaults to the granularity defined upon
entity creation.

'}, {'created': '2014-07-18 20:38:55.000000000', 'message': 'Extension for moving aggregation in API layer

Added extension for moving average, moving variance,
and exponentially weighted moving average (tested using
InfluxdB as backend). With test.

Query syntax (recognizes two parameters, granularity and center):

GET /v1/entity/UUID/measures?aggregation=moving-average&
	granularity=30s&center=False
or

GET /v1/entity/UUID/measures?aggregation=moving-variance&
	granularity=60s&center=False

or

GET/v1/entity/UUID/measures?aggregation=ewma&granularity=60s

This changes the representation of granularity overall;
now it must be a valid frequency string.

Change-Id: If40e58480f1512dd17b9c09cb75fd54c7193c257

'}, {'created': '2014-09-15 15:45:00.000000000', 'message': 'Extension for moving aggregation in API layer

Added extension for moving average, moving variance,
ewma. Unit tests added.

Query syntax (recognizes two parameters, granularity and center):

    GET /v1/entity/UUID/measures?aggregation=moving-average&
	granularity=30S&center=False
or
    GET /v1/entity/UUID/measures?aggregation=ewma&granularity=60S

If granularity is not specified, the moving aggregates are computed
on the data using the coarsest archive granularity. If 1S resolution
data is not available, the moving aggregates are performed on the
rolled-up timeseries.

Change-Id: If40e58480f1512dd17b9c09cb75fd54c7193c257
'}, {'created': '2014-10-03 22:05:33.000000000', 'message': 'Extension for moving aggregation in API layer

Added extension for moving average, moving variance,
ewma. Unit tests added.

Query syntax (recognizes two parameters, window and center):

    GET /v1/entity/UUID/measures?aggregation=moving-average&
	window=30S&center=False
or
    GET /v1/entity/UUID/measures?aggregation=ewma&window=60S

The moving aggregates are performed on the timeseries which
has the smallest granularity available that covers the timespan
requested. A 404 response code is returned for invalid
or missing parameters.

Change-Id: If40e58480f1512dd17b9c09cb75fd54c7193c257

    GET /v1/entity/UUID/measures?aggregation=moving-average&
	window=30S&center=False
or
    GET /v1/entity/UUID/measures?aggregation=ewma&window=60S

The moving aggregates are performed on the timeseries which
has the smallest granularity available that covers the timespan
requested. A 404 response code is returned for invalid
or missing parameters.

Change-Id: If40e58480f1512dd17b9c09cb75fd54c7193c257

    GET /v1/entity/UUID/measures?aggregation=moving-average&
	window=30S&resolution=high
or
    GET /v1/entity/UUID/measures?aggregation=ewma&window=60S

The moving aggregates are performed on the rolled-up data
with granularity that factors into the window size. Resolution
'high' finds the finest granularity data; resolution 'low'
finds the coarsest granularity data. A 404 response code
is returned for invalid or missing parameters.

commit_message:
Extension for moving aggregation in API layer

Added extension for moving average, moving variance,
ewma. Unit tests added.

Query syntax (required parameter: window. optional: center,
resolution):

    GET /v1/entity/UUID/measures?aggregation=moving-average&
	window=30S&resolution=high
or
    GET /v1/entity/UUID/measures?aggregation=ewma&window=60S

The moving aggregates are performed on the rolled-up data
with granularity that factors into the window size. Resolution
'high' finds the finest granularity data; resolution 'low'
finds the coarsest granularity data. A 404 response code
is returned for invalid or missing parameters.

Change-Id: If40e58480f1512dd17b9c09cb75fd54c7193c257

commit_message:
allow image_id for imageRef in create volume API

This adds support for replacing the imageRef key with image_id when
creating a volume in both v1 and v2 of the Cinder API.

Closes-Bug: 1375867

Change-Id: I6770de8f70e00a3c8dc27ecf8dd88b3586b842ea

commit_message:
Add pool_id column to Domains Table

 This adds the pool_id column to the domains table
 along with the necessary code changes and tests as
 part of all the changes that need to be done to
 accomodate server pools

 Partially-implements: blueprint server-pools-storage

 - Migrate servers from servers table to
   poolattributes table
 - Remove all old server api code
 - Make changes to backends to use poolattribute
   nameservers instead of servers

Change-Id: I535a04cac27d1068398fd982ca14016c38cbd134

commit_message:
policy.json: Allow one to manage them from the puppet module

This commit allow a deployer to manage the policies via this module
It relies on augeas to change only the policy needed. The init takes
a hash of policies and apply them.

Change-Id: If41f08571577bb799a373202dc58c2577bbe7f74

commit_message:
policy.json: Allow one to manage them from the puppet module

This commit allow a deployer to manage the policies via this module
It relies on augeas to change only the policy needed. The init takes
a hash of policies and apply them.

Change-Id: I398fca298330b8cc5d5d7dfbf6ebed067b34f9d7

commit_message:
Added metadata lint and puppet-syntax gems

metadata-json-lint is a little tool to check the validity of
Puppet metatdata.json files.

puppet-syntax tool check the validity of templates,manifests and hiera
files (the goal here is to replace manual checks in the gate by a
standard? check `rake syntax`).

Change-Id: I60b9cdfe27eeb8a8f5ad3a238dd847ed3096cb6b

commit_message:
policy.json: Allow one to manage them from the puppet module

This commit allow a deployer to manage the policies via this module
It relies on augeas to change only the policy needed. The init takes
a hash of policies and apply them.

Change-Id: I413702d5baa0e96c43f9a599e1e06ed23ab23993

- gate-manila-tempest-dsvm-neutron-multibackend http://logs.openstack.org/19/124519/3/check/gate-manila-tempest-dsvm-neutron-multibackend/5dba8ab : SUCCESS in 31m 53s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 11047, 'date': '2014-09-29 18:54:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

Might want to fix one odd capital "F".

I also noticed inconsistent use of one-word "backend" vs "back-end" and I think in official docs we tend to use "back end", but since we use it different ways in docs and config keys and now the word multi-backend, I think all varieties are pretty acceptable.  Maybe you could find a standard for us all to work on.'}, {'account_id': 9186, 'date': '2014-09-29 21:09:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6491, 'date': '2014-09-30 04:24:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(5 comments)

Thanks Bob and Mark. Will address your comments in the next patch.

Mark,
I noticed the official doc uses "back end" as well. I wasn't sure whether I should follow that because we use "backend" in other places.'}, {'account_id': 11047, 'date': '2014-09-30 16:39:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

Replied to your reply on "File Storage" capitalization, or not.

Regarding "backend", "back end", "back-end": I does read just fine any way.  I _think_ we use 2 words in docs sentences but use 1 word in config vars and example names.  So I _think_ it would be good to avoid the 3rd option, the hyphen. Otherwise, I give up. They all work and look OK.'}, {'account_id': 8851, 'date': '2014-09-30 17:06:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6491, 'date': '2014-10-01 04:01:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 11047, 'date': '2014-10-01 04:06:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6491, 'date': '2014-10-01 04:08:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)

I changed the term to "multiple-storage back ends" to be consistent with the official doc. "back ends" or "back end" is usually used as a noun. "back-end" is usually used as an adjective.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-10-01 04:14:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified-1

Netty is used for messaging.

Change-Id: Iff91dfc96d9644087f0b32c1ce694c20d9e14d3a
'}, {'created': '2014-11-07 12:27:19.000000000', 'message': 'Remove ZeroMQ installation

ZeroMQ is not necessary anymore for Storm. Without ZeroMQ the default

commit_message:
Remove ZeroMQ installation

ZeroMQ is not necessary anymore for Storm. Without ZeroMQ the default
Netty is used for messaging.

Closes-bug: #1390446
Change-Id: Iff91dfc96d9644087f0b32c1ce694c20d9e14d3a

[{'created': '2014-11-03 02:13:33.000000000', 'message': 'Add cassandra-driver>=2.1.1 requirement

Apache 2 licensed; needed for Cassandra support in Ceilometer

Change-Id: I5803f93be601b875fdfb8276c04e7ecebab8d08e
'}, {'created': '2014-11-07 15:24:05.000000000', 'message': 'Add cassandra-driver>=2.1.1 requirement

Apache 2 licensed; needed for Cassandra support in Ceilometer

> Is the library actively maintained?

This is the official DataStax library and actively maintains it.
https://github.com/datastax/python-driver

> Is the library good code?

Yes.

> Is the library python 3 compatible?

Yes.

> Is the library license compatible?

Yes: Apache2

> Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu latest /
> Fedora latest)?

Packaged by DataStax, and in PyPi.  Not yet in Ubuntu / Fedora.

However, this is only going to be an _optional_ requirement.  If users do not
enable the Cassandra backend for Ceilometer, they will not use it.  As such,
this is a weaker requirement for packaging OpenStack.

Indeed, it would likely be inappropriate to install the Cassandra driver as part
of a default OpenStack distro, as Cassandra is not a primary datastore for any
OpenStack project.

As such, I do not believe we are requiring the distros to package it.  They may
choose to do so for the convenience of their users, but that is their choice.

> Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries in
> global-requirements.txt?

No

Change-Id: I5803f93be601b875fdfb8276c04e7ecebab8d08e
'}, {'created': '2014-11-07 15:26:00.000000000', 'message': 'Add cassandra-driver>=2.1.1 requirement

Indeed, it would likely be inappropriate to install the Cassandra driver as part

OpenStack project.

As such, I do not believe we are requiring the distros to package it.  They may
choose to do so for the convenience of their users, but that is their choice.

> Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries in
> global-requirements.txt?

No

Change-Id: I5803f93be601b875fdfb8276c04e7ecebab8d08e

commit_message:
Add cassandra-driver>=2.1.1 requirement

Apache 2 licensed; needed for Cassandra support in Ceilometer

> Is the library actively maintained?

This is the official DataStax library and they actively maintain it.
https://github.com/datastax/python-driver

> Is the library good code?

Yes.

> Is the library python 3 compatible?

Yes.

> Is the library license compatible?

Yes: Apache2

> Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu latest /
> Fedora latest)?

Packaged by DataStax, and in PyPi.  Not yet in Ubuntu / Fedora.

However, this is only going to be an _optional_ requirement.  If users do not
enable the Cassandra backend for Ceilometer, they will not use it.  As such,
this is a weaker requirement for packaging OpenStack.

Indeed, it would likely be inappropriate to install the Cassandra driver as part
of a default OpenStack distro, as Cassandra is not a primary datastore for any
OpenStack project.

As such, I do not believe we are requiring the distros to package it.  They may
choose to do so for the convenience of their users, but that is their choice.

> Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries in
> global-requirements.txt?

No

Change-Id: I5803f93be601b875fdfb8276c04e7ecebab8d08e

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-10-16 01:10:47.000000000', 'message': 'Guard against concurrent port removal in DVR

The delete_csnat_router_interface_ports method is called after
other methods that can yield to send updates
(_remove_interface_by_subnet or _remove_interface_by_port).
During the yield, another API call may delete the port that
delete_csnat_router_interface_ports intends to delete.

This patch verifies that the port db object is actually present
before trying to extract the ID from it.

Closes-Bug: #1381263
Change-Id: Ia371545d641aaa1cbaa0fd10cd233250ec5769e5
'}, {'created': '2014-10-16 05:37:31.000000000', 'message': "Guard against concurrent port removal in DVR

The delete_csnat_router_interface_ports method constructs
a generator expression to retrieve the ports attached
to a router. If a concurrent process manages to delete
one of the ports referenced in the generator from the DB
after it is constructed (but before iteration), some of the
ports will be None objects on iteration.

This patch verifies that the port db object is there
before trying to extract the ID from it.

More details:

This is because the query expression[1] is evaluated immediately
at the time the generator is defined. If there are ports in the
DB at the time of this evaluation, RouterPort objects will be
prepared to be iterated over. However, before the iteration over the
generator happens, something else may delete the port from the DB.
If that happens, when the iteration starts and the 'port' attribute
is accessed on the router port, a SELECT statement will be issued to
the DB to get that port[2] and it will return None.

1. router.attached_ports.filter_by(port_type=DEVICE_OWNER_DVR_SNAT)
2. The RouterPorts table's relationship to the Ports table is using
   the default 'select' lazy loading.

Closes-Bug: #1381263
Change-Id: Ia371545d641aaa1cbaa0fd10cd233250ec5769e5
"}]
commit_message:
Guard against concurrent port removal in DVR

The delete_csnat_router_interface_ports method constructs
a generator expression to retrieve the ports attached
to a router. If a concurrent process manages to delete
one of the ports referenced in the generator from the DB
after it is constructed (but before iteration), some of the
ports will be None objects on iteration.

This patch verifies that the port db object is there
before trying to extract the ID from it.

More details:

This is because the query expression[1] is evaluated immediately
at the time the generator is defined. If there are ports in the
DB at the time of this evaluation, RouterPort objects will be
prepared to be iterated over. However, before the iteration over the
generator happens, something else may delete the port from the DB.
If that happens, when the iteration starts and the 'port' attribute
is accessed on the router port, a SELECT statement will be issued to
the DB to get that port[2] and it will return None.

1. router.attached_ports.filter_by(port_type=DEVICE_OWNER_DVR_SNAT)
2. The RouterPorts table's relationship to the Ports table is using
   the default 'select' lazy loading.

Closes-Bug: #1381263
Change-Id: Ia371545d641aaa1cbaa0fd10cd233250ec5769e5

[{'created': '2014-08-27 01:26:41.000000000', 'message': 'Remove single occurrence of lost-exception warning

Returning within a finally block can be surprising since the finally
block will "hijack" the regular return flow.  In this case, pylint is
trying to warn us that the return-within-finally would discard the
earlier caught exception.  For this particular function we don't care
that the exception is lost, so the existing code is correct but possibly
confusing.

Our options are:
1. Disable the lost-exception warning for this function
2. Rewrite the function to avoid return-within-finally

This change takes approach (2), since the required change is trivial.

This change also enables the corresponding pylint check now that the
only offending case has been removed.

Change-Id: If1706851b4bd67ebdbbdb3485984773598efdf7a

commit_message:
Remove single occurrence of lost-exception warning

Returning within a finally block can be surprising since the finally
block will "hijack" the regular return flow.  In this case, pylint is
trying to warn us that the return-within-finally would discard the
earlier caught exception.  For this particular function we don't care
that the exception is lost, so the existing code is correct but possibly
confusing.

Our options are:
1. Disable the lost-exception warning for this function
2. Rewrite the function to avoid return-within-finally

This change takes approach (2), since the required change is trivial.

This change also enables the corresponding pylint check now that the
only offending case has been removed.

Change-Id: If1706851b4bd67ebdbbdb3485984773598efdf7a

commit_message:
Using Taskflow to refactor Volume Backup Delete

Refactor the volume backup delete code to use Taskflow
(https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/TaskFlow).
Split volume backup delete code into tasks that perform
the individual required actions to accomplish the pieces
desired outcome. Implementing long-running operations via
task flows is needed, so we can better control the operation
process.
blueprint volume-backup-delete-task-flow

Change-Id: I029313cde65c0700cf714278fcbb99d64da69fc7

commit_message:
Using Taskflow to refactor Volume Backup Restore

Refactor the volume backup restore code to use Taskflow
(https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/TaskFlow).
Split volume backup restore code into tasks that perform
the individual required actions to accomplish the pieces
desired outcome. Implementing long-running operations via
task flows is needed, so we can better control the operation
process.

blueprint volume-backup-restore-task-flow

Change-Id: I20e441ac95cd466ddedb703496beb66fc43f4e70

Turns out that it just prepares the text here...


> I'd like to get an update if you're still interested
> in helping us out with this and get this approved if so.
We are, very much so!


Thanks for the reminder.'}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2014-11-08 23:08:54.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Cinder volume driver using DRBD

This BluePrint/Spec proposes a new Cinder volume driver,
which uses DRBDmanage to provide replicated storage.

Change-Id: Id02feeac808bb6db585f929c3c06db207bcf23e4

subject: Add blueprint for tag-volume
messages:
[{'account_id': 8874, 'date': '2014-06-11 09:32:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-11 09:32:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-11 09:32:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded.

- noop http://logs.openstack.org/05/99305/1/check/noop/38cac00 : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 1207, 'date': '2014-06-11 09:55:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

We already have metadata, this is just metadata light. Just introduce a convention for a metadata key called 'tags' and do the work in the clients. No need for a new API at all."}, {'account_id': 4355, 'date': '2014-06-11 16:17:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Agree with Duncan'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-16 09:00:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Verified

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 8874, 'date': '2014-06-16 09:00:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

To Duncan Thomas & Avishay Traeger:
	As the mailist discussion of http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-April/033222.html,
we know that different projects and different objects in one project use different key/value methods to classify/filter 
objects.
As the mailist discussion, openstack system needs a uniform way to classify/filter objects in the same way.
Since nova is beginning to support tag objects, cinder and other projects also need to support tag 
mechanism to classify/filter objects.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-16 09:00:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded.

- noop http://logs.openstack.org/05/99305/1/check/noop/51e059f : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 1207, 'date': '2014-06-16 11:41:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The fact that nova supports something is certainly not an automatic reason for cinder to support it! We've rejected that kind of argument before and will very much continue.

What's wrong with doing it all on the client side with a metadata item called 'tags'? No cinder changes required at all..."}, {'account_id': 10247, 'date': '2014-06-16 13:20:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I agree with Duncan that the fact that nova supports it is not an automatic reason for cinder (or any other module) to support it. Implementing the functionality in cinder client seems like a good plan to me. 

That said, I think that nova folks have not agreed yet on the implementation: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/91444/ and there's a comment from John Garbutt asking to discuss the tagging api across projects. We should share the cinder client approach with them"}, {'account_id': 8874, 'date': '2014-06-17 03:52:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

To Duncan Thomas & Santiago Baldassin:
1. I still think it's a trend for cinder to support tag.
2. Tags are used to logically classify and filter objects.
3. If cinder use metadata key tag to support tagging mechanism,
how should client do to get a total classify/filter tags to
know the whole classification?
Firstly, client needs to do a volume detail query to cinder. 
Secondly, client extract/dedup all the metadata tag key from query response.
Thirdly, client extract/dedup all the metadata tag values.

If there many more volume items in cinder, it should be a big burden for cinder
while client does many volume details query to cinder.
Also it would be a burden for client to extract/dedup metadata tag and its value.

If cinder supports tagging mechanism, it would push less load on cinder and client.
In addition, using tagging mechanism implemented in cinder, we could more effectively 
classify/filter objects."}, {'account_id': 1207, 'date': '2014-06-17 10:51:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

Splitting, de-duping and processing a text string per volume on the client is a load so trivial it is not worth talking about.

Retrieving tags is probably always going to require a detailed get, they aren't important enough to go in the default view.

I'm still no seeing a single advantage to adding a specific tags api."}, {'account_id': 8874, 'date': '2014-06-20 03:19:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

TO Duncan Thomas?

Curently different projects and different objects in one project use different key/value methods to classify/filter objects, detail discussion in http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-April/033222.html.

With the development of whole openstack system and more collaboration between projects, it is necessary to uniform the "tag" way on objects in whole openstack system in some day, may be not fow now. 
Two benifits, only for the individual opinion, are long term benefits:
1. Inside Openstack: Provide an uniform tagging way for projects to interact more effectively.
2. Outside Openstack: facilitating clients to integrate with OpenStack.

Anyway, thanks for your opinion.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-20 03:19:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Verified

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-20 03:19:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded.

- noop http://logs.openstack.org/05/99305/1/check/noop/f49a0c5 : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 1207, 'date': '2014-06-20 14:21:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Key-value pairs are a superset of tags, you can trivially implement tags on top of it, but not the converse, no cinder change it required.'}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2014-11-08 22:58:11.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

Add tagging mechanism for the volume object.

'}]

blueprint tag-volume

commit_message:
Added a spec for volume type description change

The purpose of this spec is to address the issue of current volume
type's lacking of information. The spec lays out how to improve
the volume type by adding the description information and
allowing user to find out what is the default volume type.

Change-Id: I6d92cd327b60024ad7f067ddcfc32bf70952f58d

ML2 mechanism driver for Cisco Nexus1000V

Adds the specification for a new ML2 mechanism driver for

commit_message:
carbonara: fix archive back window

The back window allowed was too large; it should be only 1 block_size
and not 2 block_size.

Change-Id: I44e40ec267761e099a8cb55ac976100e719ed013

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Gerrit_Workflow

commit_message:
Explicitly specifies cm_api version in CDH plugin

We set CM_API_VERSION value in cloudera_utils.py, and in function
get_api_client, we add augment version to api_client.ApiResource
whose default value is CM_API_VERSION. Currently this value is set
to 7.

Closes-Bug: #1387960
Change-Id: I54e19c0c39357c410b070df1315ec3a7eb68740d

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-29 00:16:18.000000000', 'message': 'Reorganize DbTestCase to use provisioning completely.

This change is the first part in a series of changes
that will allow for full flexibility in database usage
during tests.   The first step is to add more facility
to the oslo.db.sqlalchemy.provision system, implementing
a dispatch system that allows flexibility in creation
and dropping of databases, as well as moving the awareness
of the "openstack_citest" convention into provisioning.
The OpportunisticFixture and OpportunisticTestCase now
fold into DbFixture and DbTestCase, which defers in a simple
way to provision.ProvisionedDatabase for all connectivity.
ProvisionedDatabase in turn decides based on the given
environment as to how an engine should be provisioned
for a given test.

Future changes will allow provisioning to hold onto a single
database engine per test run, as well as allow a single
test class to run in multiple backend scenarios (e.g. one test
against many different backends).

Change-Id: Ifc02505c4c8ebd4a1ca56e14f76c0989576875c3
Partially-Closes-Bug: 1340395
'}, {'created': '2014-07-29 00:24:26.000000000', 'message': 'Reorganize DbTestCase to use provisioning completely.

during tests.   The first step is to add more facility
to the oslo.db.sqlalchemy.provision system, implementing
a dispatch system that allows flexibility in creation
and dropping of databases, as well as moving the awareness
of the "openstack_citest" convention into provisioning.
The OpportunisticFixture and OpportunisticTestCase now
fold into DbFixture and DbTestCase, which defers in a simple
way to provision.ProvisionedDatabase for all connectivity.
ProvisionedDatabase in turn decides based on the given
environment as to how an engine should be provisioned
for a given test.

Future changes will allow provisioning to hold onto a single
database engine per test run, as well as allow a single
test class to run in multiple backend scenarios (e.g. one test
against many different backends).

Change-Id: Ifc02505c4c8ebd4a1ca56e14f76c0989576875c3
Partially-Closes-Bug: 1339206
